fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.models.interfaces

Interface ModelI

  • All Superinterfaces:
    ModelDescriptionI
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    AtomicModelI, CoupledModelI
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AtomicES_Model, AtomicHIOA, AtomicHIOAwithDE, AtomicHIOAwithEquations, AtomicModel, BatterySensorModel, ControllerModel, CoupledModel, Model, MoleneModel, NetworkModel, PortableComputerModel, PortableComputerStateModel, ServerModel, Tic_ES_Model, TicModel, WiFiBandwidthModel, WiFiBandwidthSensorModel, WiFiDisconnectionModel, WiFiModel

    public interface ModelI
extends ModelDescriptionI
    The interface ModelI is the root of the type hierarchy defining variants of DEVS simulation models for a component plug-in implementing a family of DEVS simulation engines.

    Description

    DEVS is a simulation protocol that implements modular discrete event simulation models which can then be simulated in a centralised or distributed way.

    B.P. Zeigler, H. Praehofer et T.G. Kim, Theory of Modeling and Simulation, Academic Press, 2nd edition, 2000.

    Debugging facilities

    DEVS models all share the fact that they have a unique identifier (URI), a simulation time unit used by their simulation clock and a simulation engine enacting them. Besides these standard services, models can be traced at execution for debugging purposes. The interface defines methods to control this debugging facility.

    Created on : 2016-03-25

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

 post    ret != null

        the simulation engine instance currently running this model.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.

      • isCoordinated

        boolean isCoordinated()
               throws java.lang.Exception
        return true if the simulation engine is coordinated by a parent.

        Description

        In DEVS, simulation can operate in different mode. The traditional mode confers to the coupled models and their coordination engine the role to pilot the advance of their submodels keeping a global synchronisation between the simulation clocks of their submodels. In real time, atomic models and their simulation engine operate on their own without being coordinated by parent coupled models and their coordination engines.

        This method allows to know when a model is coordinated and when it is not.

        Contract

         pre    true                    // no precondition.
 post   true                    // no postcondition.
        Returns:
        true if the simulation engine is coordinated by a parent.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.

         pre     simParams != null && simParams.size() > 0
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        simParams - map from parameters names to their values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.

      • initialiseState

        void initialiseState()
        initialise the state of the model to make it ready to execute a simulation run with default initial time set to 0.

        Description

        Specific models rarely redefine this method; they should rather redefine the method initialiseState(Time initialTime) with the initial time argument.

        Contract

         pre    true            // no precondition.
 post    isInitialised()

      • initialiseState

        void initialiseState(Time initialTime)
        initialise the state of the model to make it ready to execute a simulation run.

        Description

        The standard predefined state initialisation will set the time to the next event. Hence, if a specific model has to perform some initialisations which the first internal transition depends upon, it must first perform them and then call the inherited method using super.

        Contract

         pre     initialTime != null
 pre     initialTime.greaterThanOrEqual(Time.zero(getSimulatedTimeUnit()))
 post    isInitialised()
        Parameters:
        initialTime - time of the simulation when it will start.

      • getCurrentStateTime

 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Returns:
        the current simulation time at which the model executed its last event.

      • getNextTimeAdvance

        Duration getNextTimeAdvance()
        return the duration until the next internal event as previously computed by timeAdvance() but in a side effect free manner.

        Description

        In the DEVS protocol, the function timeAdvance return the duration until the next internal event, but it is assumed to be a pure function. In an object-oriented implementation, the user (who implements timeAdvance) may have to implement it with some side effects on the object representing the model. Hence, it should be called only once each time an internal event is executed. If the user need to access this value again, he/seh must be provided with a side effect free way to do so. This method does exactly that.

        Contract

         pre    true            // no precondition.
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Returns:
        the duration until the next internal event as previously computed by timeAdvance().

      • getTimeOfNextEvent

        Time getTimeOfNextEvent()
        return the time at which the next internal event will happen in a side effect free manner.

        Description

        In the standard purely functional definition of the DEVS protocol, this method would not be required, as it is the addition of the result of the function timeAdvance and the current simulated time of the model. In this object-oriented implementation, the user may implement timeAdvance with some side effects, hence if he/she needs to access this information elsewhere, a side effect free way to do so must be provided. This method does exactly that.

        Contract

         pre    true            // no precondition.
 post    ret != null
        Returns:
        the time at which the next internal event will happen.

      • timeAdvance

        Duration timeAdvance()
        return the time the simulated system remains in the current state before making a transition to the next sequential state; the method must be implemented by the user in each atomic model.

        Contract

         pre    true            // no precondition.
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Returns:
        the time the simulated system remains in the current state before making an internal transition to the next state.

      • internalTransition

        void internalTransition()
        perform the next internal transition, both calling the method userDefinedInternalTransition and doing all of the necessary internal catering work.

        Description

        In the standard DEVS protocol, this method is assumed to be defined by users in their atomic models. However, having only one method to do so makes it difficult to include common behaviours for models. Moreover, DEVS allows to define new types of models where specific common behaviours must be implemented. With the traditional DEVS vision, this would end up asking the users to cater for these common behaviours in each of their implementations the method, an error-prone burden put on their shoulders. In this library, we prefer to split transitions in two parts:

        • a library defined part, here internalTransition, which implementations in abstract classes include their common behaviours and, for atomic models, calls the user model specific part;
        • a user model-specific part, here userDefinedInternalTransition, which implements the execution internal events of the user-defined models per se.

        After the execution of the method, the relationships between timeAdvance, getTimeOfNextEvent, getNextTimeAdvance and getCurrentStateTime() is restored to reflect the wait for the next internal event.

        Contract

         pre     getTimeOfNextEvent().lessThan(Time.INFINITY)
 pre     getNextTimeAdvance().equals(getTimeOfNextEvent().subtract(getCurrentStateTime()))
 post    getTimeOfNextEvent().equals(Time.INFINITY) || getTimeOfNextEvent().subtract(getCurrentStateTime()).equals(getNextTimeAdvance())

      • userDefinedInternalTransition

        void userDefinedInternalTransition(Duration elapsedTime)
        perform an internal transition; this method is user model-dependent hence must be implemented by the user for atomic models; the user implementation should not change any of the implementation related variables.

        Description

        The current simulation time when this method is called can be accessed by calling the method getCurrentStateTime.

        Contract

         pre     isInitialised()
 pre     getCurrentStateTime().equals(getTimeOfNextEvent())
 pre     elapsedTime != null
 pre     elapsedTime.greaterThanOrEqual(Duration.zero(getSimulatedTimeUnit()))
 pre     elapsedTime.lessThan(Duration.INFINITY)
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        elapsedTime - time since the last event.

      • causalTransition

        void causalTransition(Time current)
        perform a causal transition i.e., an internal transition triggered by the internal transition of an influenced model; causal transitions do not produce external events.

        Description

        This method has been introduced by the library when the HIOA models defined by algebraic equations were introduced in order to allow an implementation that reevaluates variables on request only. For other models, new variable values and events are produced by the execution of events, but in this case, this allows an influenced model to require new values only when they are needed this reducing the computational workload.

        Therefore, the causal transition should be used to implement a lazy evaluation of the variables upon which another variable depends in another model. In this case, the internal transition of the depending model will trigger causal transitions on each of the models that provide values for variables upon which the former depends. This is indeed recursive. For example, imagine a model A that depends upon variables provided by models B and C, with C also depending on variables provided by a model D. Then, one can program the model A such that it has planned internal transitions to update its variables, but all of the others would have no planned internal transitions but only causal transitions triggered by the internal transition of A. In this case, the models will be sorted in dependency order D, C, B, A and then each of them will be activated for causal transition (D, C, B) and for internal transition (A). For HIOA models, this can force a unique integration step for all variables or perform a lazy update for variables that are computed using an algebraic equation.

        Of course, one can also decide to have internal transitions only and therefore decide locally to each HIOA model when to update their variables. In this case, depending models use the latest value of all of the variables they depend upon, which can cause larger numerical errors. When a unique integration step must be chosen among several variables so to minimise the numerical errors for all of the variables, the inherent coupling that this supposes should push the programmer to create a single model to integrate all of these variables together. Otherwise, their would be a need for a dynamic negotiation of the integration steps hard to put in place within the DEVS protocol.

        Contract

         pre     isInitialised()
 pre     current != null
 pre     current.greaterThanOrEqual(getCurrentStateTime())
 pre     current.lessThanOrEqual(this.getTimeOfNextEvent())
 pre     getCurrentStateTime().lessThanOrEqual(getTimeOfNextEvent())
 post    getTimeOfNextEvent().equals(Time.INFINITY) || getTimeOfNextEvent().subtract(getCurrentStateTime()).equals(getNextTimeAdvance())
        Parameters:
        current - current simulation time.

      • userDefinedCausalTransition

        void userDefinedCausalTransition(Duration elapsedTime)
        perform a causal transition; this method is user model-dependent hence must be implemented by the user for atomic models; the user implementation should not change any of the implementation related variables.

        Description

        The current simulation time when this method is called can be accessed by calling the method getCurrentStateTime.

 pre     elapsedTime.greaterThanOrEqual(Duration.zero(getSimulatedTimeUnit()))
 pre     elapsedTime.lessThan(Duration.INFINITY)
 pre     getCurrentStateTime().lessThanOrEqual(getTimeOfNextEvent())
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:

      • externalTransition

        void externalTransition(Duration elapsedTime)
        do the next external transition, both calling the method userDefinedExternalTransition and doing all of the necessary internal catering work.

        Description

        In the standard DEVS protocol, this method is assumed to be defined by users in their atomic models. However, having only one method to do so makes it difficult to include common behaviours for models. Moreover, DEVS allows to define new types of models where specific common behaviours must be implemented. With the traditional DEVS vision, this would end up asking the users to cater for these common behaviours in each of their implementations the method, an error-prone burden put on their shoulders. In this library, we prefer to split transitions in two parts:

        • a library defined part, here externalTransition, which implementations in abstract classes include their common behaviours and, for atomic models, calls the user model specific part;
        • a user model-specific part, here userDefinedExternalTransition, which implements the execution internal events of the user-defined models per se.

        After the execution of the method, the relationships between timeAdvance, getTimeOfNextEvent(), getNextTimeAdvance and getCurrentStateTime() is restored to reflect the wait for the next internal event.

        Contract

         pre     isInitialised()
 pre     elapsedTime != null
 pre     elapsedTime.greaterThanOrEqual(Duration.zero(getSimulatedTimeUnit()))
 pre     elapsedTime.lessThanOrEqual(getNextTimeAdvance())
 pre     getCurrentStateTime().lessThanOrEqual(getTimeOfNextEvent())
 post    getTimeOfNextEvent().equals(Time.INFINITY) || getTimeOfNextEvent().subtract(getCurrentStateTime()).equals(getNextTimeAdvance())
        Parameters:
        elapsedTime - elapsed time since the last transition.

      • userDefinedExternalTransition

        void userDefinedExternalTransition(Duration elapsedTime)
        do an external transition using a previously stored external input event; this method is user-model-dependent hence must be implemented by the user for atomic models; the user implementation should not change any of the implementation related variables.

        Description

        The current simulation time when this method is called can be accessed by calling the method getCurrentStateTime.

        Contract

         pre     isInitialised()
 pre     elapsedTime != null
 pre     elapsedTime.greaterThanOrEqual(Duration.zero(getSimulatedTimeUnit()))
 pre     elapsedTime.lessThanOrEqual(getNextTimeAdvance())
 pre     getCurrentStateTime().lessThanOrEqual(getTimeOfNextEvent())
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        elapsedTime - simulation time since the last processed event.

      • confluentTransition

      • produceOutput

        void produceOutput(Time current)
        force the model to forward externals event generated before their next internal transition step.

        Description

        The implementation follows the principle of the "peer message exchanging implementation" i.e., the simulators exchanges directly with each others the exported and imported events without passing by their parent (and ancestors).

        Contract

         pre     current != null
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        current - current simulation time at which external events may be output.

      • endSimulation

        void endSimulation(Time endTime)
            throws java.lang.Exception
        terminate the current simulation.

        Description

        This method can be user-defined, allowing to perform some catering work like gathering data or computing statistics that depends upon the end time of the simulation (and that would likely be included in the simulation report of the model).

        Contract

         pre    true            // no precondition.
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        endTime - time at which the simulation ends.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.
